answers.answer: The A1c is an AVERAGE of you BG over 3 months  So yes you can have an average A1c of 5.7 and a fasting BG of 89The A1c is not tha same scale or even measuring the same thing.the A1c measures how much Glucose is stuck to your red blood cells.  Red Blood cells live about 3 months, the higher your BG the more Glucose gets stuck to your red blood cells.An A1c of 5.7 means your AVERAGE BG was 116   so if they test you BG at 89  that means at some point your BG had to be much higher. to average to 116.Hope I didnt confuse you more

question: I am little confused about my test results. Diabetes runs rampant in my family so it has always been a concern to me. I had a total thyroidectomy in Aug 2008 and am now Hypothyroid. Keeping myself at a healthy weight since my surgery has been extremely tough and nearly impossible. I had gotten my A1c and glucose checked in 10/27/2012 and  my lab results came back with my: Hemoglobin A1c 5.6  Glucose 85 mg/dl. I have since lost close to 20 lbs through diet and exercise. On 6/22/2013, I got another set of tests taken. I have gone back to the Dr since then for my follow up, she had received my new results and didn't mention anything concerning other than my thyroid was off, yet again, and sent me on my way. Today, I received my test results frim the lab and my Hemoglobin A1c is 5.7 (H) and Glucose 89 mg/dl. I've read other posts that state those results aren't even possible. Can someone please explain this to me?
title: A1c confusion
